content: Since 9/11, domestic terrorists drawing inspiration from U.S.-based extremist ideologies have not received as much attention from federal law enforcement as violent jihadists. The FBI reported in 1999 that most deadly terrorist attacks in the U.S. were perpetrated by domestic extremists. The U.S. government enhanced counterterrorism efforts post-9/11, shaping the landscape largely in response to foreign-inspired terrorists. This report discusses how domestic terrorists fit into the counterterrorism landscape and how they are conceptualized by the federal government. The federal government struggles to assess the significance of domestic terrorism due to varying terminology and tactics used by those labeled as domestic terrorists. Unlike foreign-inspired jihadists, domestic terrorists often rely on non-traditional tactics such as theft and property destruction, leading to their secondary status as a threat at the federal level.
